page.title: 04THE DYMCHURCH SEA WALL
page.content: The sea wall has been essential to Romney Marsh local history for hundreds of years. The Southern Water Authority is in charge of its maintenance. The present construction is stone and brick. The sea wall is under continuous repair. Workmen test for weakness by drilling into the wall, they then pour in concrete. In June 1985, six men were replacing some of the large stone cubes near the base of the wall on the seaward side. The sea wall near Beach Estate is sixty metres thick at the base, and narrows to about three metres at the top. It slopes gently up from the sea and drops away sharply to the road at the other side. This design slows down the sea and a seaward curve turns the waves back on themselves to take the strength from the incoming tide.
